channel.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

plugin.enable()seems like something that would be invoked by a system that wishes to enable a plugin, while plugin.onEnable() appears to be something that would be overridden by a class and invoked inside the enable function perhaps after certain things have been done.

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @Owner_Zack_of_Pwnage Owner Zack of PwnageScape
item.description:
@Owner_Zack_of_Pwnage wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:7, topic:436135”]That’s how I understood it.
This

plugin.enable();

makes more sense than

plugin.onEnable();

or

plugin.enablePlugin(); [/quote]
Me too :).

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

When using oop I find that I use “onBehavior” if I ever plan on overriding that method/function in another class and then “verb” for other methods/functions that are only used in that that specific class (most likely to be private).

With procedural languages I find myself using programmatic names.

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[code]setEnabled(Boolean b){
enabled = b;
if(enabled)
fireEnabledEvent()
else

fireDisabledEvent();

}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:16, topic:436135”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=538857.msg3943527#msg3943527 date=1331623280]

Then what would you call it (or the ‘pragmatic way’)? As in, the method for once the plugin has been enabled?

Yeah, I’m not really sure what to call it. To me, the “on*” naming seems like what would be done once the action has been completed. So “onLoad” would be for when it’s done loading, “onEnable” for when it has been enabled, “onCreate” for once it’s been created, etc.
[/quote]You’re contradicting yourself… we literally just said that’s what it should be for

Where did I contradict myself >.>[/quote]

We said it sounded like a hook, and you said:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:9, topic:436135”]It still doesn’t sound appropriate.[/quote]And then you said:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:9, topic:436135”]It still doesn’t sound appropriate. To me it would be something like

public class PluginLoader { public onEnable(final Plugin plugin) { // called when the plugins enable() method is called System.out.println(plugin + " has been enabled."); } } [/quote]When that’s exactly what a hook would be :L

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:15, topic:436135”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=538857.msg3943513#msg3943513 date=1331620757]

Then what would you call it (or the ‘pragmatic way’)? As in, the method for once the plugin has been enabled?

Yeah, I’m not really sure what to call it. To me, the “on*” naming seems like what would be done once the action has been completed. So “onLoad” would be for when it’s done loading, “onEnable” for when it has been enabled, “onCreate” for once it’s been created, etc.
[/quote]You’re contradicting yourself… we literally just said that’s what it should be for :P[/quote]

Where did I contradict myself >.>

Read full topic

So “onLoad” would be for when it’s done loading, “onEnable” for when it has been enabled, “onCreate” for once it’s been created, etc.[/quote]You’re contradicting yourself… we literally just said that’s what it should be for

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:13, topic:436135”]I agree that names should be kept short, but you name for the sake of being short. You should name for clarity.

For example

public void start();// is better than public void a();// as well as public void startEngineAndPerformInitialChecks(); [/quote]
we just do

public void Init()

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I agree that names should be kept short, but you name for the sake of being short. You should name for clarity.

For example

public void start();// is better than
public void a();// as well as
public void startEngineAndPerformInitialChecks();

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

as said, most companies have their own set of rules, where i worked:

  1. no function name shall be more than 12 characters long
  2. no variable name shall be more than 8 characters long (if used globally)
  3. avoid capitalization
    and some other stuff i forgot now,
    but in regardance to the naming, as in your example it turning on a light function means,
    Light_1()

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Davidi2:

Then what would you call it (or the ‘pragmatic way’)? As in, the method for once the plugin has been enabled?

Yeah, I’m not really sure what to call it. To me, the “on*” naming seems like what would be done once the action has been completed. So “onLoad” would be for when it’s done loading, “onEnable” for when it has been enabled, “onCreate” for once it’s been created, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:

Then what would you call it (or the ‘pragmatic way’)? As in, the method for once the plugin has been enabled?

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

It still doesn’t sound appropriate. To me it would be something like

public class PluginLoader {
    public onEnable(final Plugin plugin) {
        // called when the plugins enable() method is called
        System.out.println(plugin + " has been enabled.");
    }
}

But like I said, a lot of people use that style of naming.

<html>
    <body onLoad="load();">

    <body>
</html>

Android:

public void onCreate(Bundle bundle) {
    // called when it is created
}

Read full topic

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:5, topic:436135”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=538857.msg3943362#msg3943362 date=1331603398]
I think your examples are off.

I think a real linguistic example would be ‘enablePlugin’, not ‘onEnable’.

To me, enablePlugin and onEnable have completely different meanings.
[/quote]
likewise, enablePlugin sounds like some sort of construction process whilst onEnable sounds like a method for handling an event.[/quote]My thoughts exactly

in industry, companies have their own set of nomenclature; therefore, there is no right or wrong.

Nice answer.
Then again, it doesn’t make much sense if it states “onEnable” or “onDisable”, because those words don’t really need the “on”.

item.title: Linguistic vs. Programmatic Method Names
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

So recently, I’ve been seeing how different people name their methods/functions. The two most common types are Lingusistic (which is more natural), and Programmatic (which can improve understanding). Here’s an example of each

Linguistic:

public interface Plugin {
    public void onEnable();
    public void onDisable();
}

Programmatic:

public interface Plugin {
    public void enable();
    public void disable();
}

Now, which one of these is “correct”? Before you say “well it depends on the programmer”. Here’s the difference between the two (at least in my understanding)
Linguistic is more “natural”. So in this case it would be “on enable, do this”; whereas with Programmatic, it’s more “enable the plugin”. To me, Linguistic seems to cross from the past-tense to the present-tense (“when the plugin is enabled, this happens”) which I’ve always been told to avoid, and to keep everything in the present (“load the plugin”).

However, it seems that Linguistic is by far more popular (Android, HTML/Javascript, and Bukkit just name a few).

Read full topic
